question: Question_05_(a)
statement:
Let $\displaystyle \mu$ denote the Mobius function. If
$\displaystyle n > 1$ is an integer, show that

$\displaystyle \sum_{d \mid n}\mu(d) = 0$
sols:
First we show that the Mobius function is multiplicative. Let \emph{m}
and \emph{n} be coprime integers. Then let

$\displaystyle m = \prod_{i=1}^{M} p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}$

and

$\displaystyle n = \prod_{j=1}^{N} q_{j}^{\beta_{j}}$.

We wish to show that $\displaystyle \mu(mn) = \mu(m)\mu(n)$. Clearly, if
\emph{m} or \emph{n} contains a square prime factor, then both sides
evaluate to 0 so without loss of generality, suppose that each
$\displaystyle \alpha_{i},\beta_{j} = 1$. We break into cases based on
the number of prime factors.

\textbf{Case 1: \emph{M} and \emph{N} are both odd or both even.}. In
these cases, $\displaystyle \mu(mn) = 1$. Now, since the number of prime
factors are both odd or both even, we have that
$\displaystyle \mu(m) = \mu(n)$ and since these are now either plus or
minus 1 (we've eliminated the case when the Mobius function is 0 on
either side), we have

$\displaystyle \mu(mn) = 1 = \mu(m)^{2} = \mu(m)\mu(n)$

\textbf{Case 2: \emph{M} and \emph{N} are of opposite parity.}. Suppose
that \emph{M} is even (the argument is symmetric). In this case
$\displaystyle \mu(mn) = -1$ since we have an odd number of factors.
Now, we have that $\displaystyle \mu(m) =-1$ and
$\displaystyle \mu(n) = 1$. Thus,

$\displaystyle \mu(mn) = -1 = \mu(m)\mu(n)$

Hence the Mobius function is multiplicative.

Now, let $\displaystyle S(n) = \sum_{d \mid n}\mu(d)$. I claim that this
function is also multiplicative. For this, again let \emph{m} and
\emph{n} be coprime integers (notice that $\displaystyle S(1) = 1$). We
see that

$\displaystyle S(m)S(n) = \sum_{d \mid m}\mu(d) \sum_{e \mid n}\mu(e) = \sum_{d \mid m}\sum_{e \mid n}\mu(d)\mu(e)
= \sum_{d \mid m}\sum_{e \mid n}\mu(de)$

Now as \emph{m} and \emph{n} are coprime, we see that for any divisor
$\displaystyle h \mid mn$, we can write $\displaystyle h$ uniquely of
the form $\displaystyle h = de$ where $\displaystyle d \mid m$ and
$\displaystyle e \mid n$ and vice versa. Thus, we have

$\displaystyle S(m)S(n) = \sum_{d \mid m}\sum_{e \mid n}\mu(de) = \sum_{h \mid mn}\mu(h) = S(mn)$

showing that this function is also multiplicative. So, by
multiplicativity, it suffices to show that

$\displaystyle S(p^{a}) = 0$ where \emph{p} is a prime and \emph{a} is
an integer. Here, we have

$\displaystyle S(p^{a}) = \sum_{d \mid p^{a}}\mu(d) = \sum_{i=0}^{a}\mu(p^{i}) = \mu(1) + \mu(p) + \sum_{i=2}^{a}\mu(p^{i})$.

Notice that the last sum might be non-existent if \emph{a} is 1. In any
case, the last sum evaluates to 0 since all the terms contain a
$\displaystyle p^{2}$ factor. Notice that
$\displaystyle \mu(1)  +\mu(p) = 1 - 1 = 0$ and so
$\displaystyle S(p^{a}) = 0$ so long as \emph{a} is not 0 (which is
allowed since \emph{n} was an integer greater than 1). Thus we have a
multiplicative function which evaluates to 0 on all prime powers, hence
it must be zero for all values greater than 1 since

$\displaystyle S(n) = S\left(\prod_{j=1}^{N}q_{j}\right) = \prod_{j=1}^{N}S\left(q_{j}\right) = 0$.

This completes the proof.
hints:
Recall that the Mobius function is the function that evaluates to 1 if
\emph{n} is square-free and has an even number of prime factors, -1 if
\emph{n} is square-free and has an odd number of factors, and 0 if
\emph{n} has a square factor.

First show/recall that the Mobius function is multiplicative.

Let $\displaystyle S(n) = \sum_{d \mid n}\mu(d)$. Show that this
function is multiplicative then evaluate it on prime powers.

Note: One could solve this problem by a more direct approach however
learning about the theory of multiplicative functions is quite important
and worth doing.
